channel.title: BBC News - Home

item.title: Social care: PM to unveil overhaul of sector in England
item.description: Boris Johnson will set out plans on Tuesday, amid a Tory backlash to tax rises to cover costs.

item.title: NHS to get £5.4bn extra to deal with Covid backlog
item.description: Boris Johnson says the money will "go straight to the front line" in England over the next six months.

item.title: Afghanistan: Taliban claim to have taken Panjshir Valley
item.description: The Taliban raise their flag over Panjshir Valley, but resistance fighters deny being defeated.

item.title: MH17 plane crash: Trial hears trauma of relatives demanding justice
item.description: The Malaysian Airlines flight was downed over Ukraine in 2014, killing all 298 people on board.

item.title: The Wire star Michael K Williams found dead
item.description: The 54-year-old died from a suspected drug overdose in his New York flat, media reports say.

item.title: US Open 2021: Emma Raducanu into quarter-finals after beating Shelby Rogers
item.description: British teenager Emma Raducanu puts in another devastating performance to reach the US Open quarter-finals as her dream New York debut continues.

item.title: Red Funnel Southampton check-in kiosk flattened by lorry
item.description: Staff members and passengers rush to help three people working inside a ferry kiosk in Southampton.

item.title: Covid-19: UK passes 7 million confirmed Covid cases
item.description: The milestone comes as another 41,000 daily cases are recorded, but the real total is likely to be higher.

item.title: Arthur's Seat death: Man charged with murder of Fawziyah Javed
item.description: Kashif Anwar, 27, made no plea when he appeared in private at Edinburgh Sheriff Court.

item.title: UK fires up coal power plant as gas prices soar
item.description: The country has had to bring an old plant back online after a spike in the price of natural gas.

item.title: Channel migrants: Children among those brought ashore at Dungeness
item.description: A steady stream of crossings is thought to be have taken place amid calm waters and sunny skies.

item.title: Six Palestinian prisoners escape Israeli jail through tunnel
item.description: Israel launches a huge manhunt after six militants dig their way out of the high-security jail.

item.title: Covid-19: Table service rules over for NI pubs and restaurants
item.description: Up to 15 people are now allowed indoors in homes while dancing will be allowed at wedding receptions.

item.title: The papers: NHS tax-rise anger and October firebreak plan
item.description: A "manifesto-busting" tax rise to help pay for the NHS is among a mix of stories leading the papers.

item.title: Inside Big Ben's restoration as it nears finish
item.description: The restoration of Elizabeth Tower, which will ultimately cost at least £80 million, draws to a close.

item.title: Spider season: Why your home might feel full of arachnids right now
item.description: They're not coming through the windows - they were already inside.

item.title: 'Why not have festivals that only women can attend?'
item.description: The idea for the three-day LBTQ Femme Fest was conceived on social media during lockdown.

item.title: Students return with school restrictions lifted
item.description: Students across the UK are returning to school after the summer break and and a year disrupted by Covid.

item.title: Dune: Critics largely lavish praise on epic sci-fi remake
item.description: The blockbuster had its world premiere at the Venice International Film Festival over the weekend.

item.title: 'I've raised £100,000 after 24 years of coffee mornings'
item.description: Eleanor Moffat has spent more than 20 years organising charity events after her sister was diagnosed with cancer.

item.title: Black interns: 'You just need to give us a chance'
item.description: Young black university students are being invited to apply for 2,000 internships at top companies.

item.title: Saving Australian frog species on the brink of extinction
item.description: Scientists fear four species are already extinct but say urgent action can save others.

item.title: South Africa danger zone: Living in a 'hijacked' building
item.description: Pictures of squatters in a South African inner city with high levels of crime, drugs and prostitution.

item.title: Khalid Sheikh Mohammed: How '9/11 mastermind' slipped through FBI's fingers
item.description: Could the man accused of hatching the plot to fly planes into US landmarks 20 years ago have been stopped?

item.title: Jean-Paul Belmondo: Cool rebel of French cinema
item.description: Star of Breathless, Jean-Paul Belmondo was one of France's most popular actors.

item.title: Sarah Harding: She was always going at 100mph
item.description: The team behind Girls Aloud's biggest hits remember Sarah Harding who's died at the age of 39.

item.title: Building supplies shortages: 'I can't see it getting better any time soon'
item.description: Builders are struggling to get hold of key supplies, and the shortages are pushing prices higher.

item.title: 'A hotel without linen is not a hotel'
item.description: The laundry firms that provide bed linen for hotels across the UK are facing an unprecedented crisis.

item.title: Social care: What would a National Insurance rise mean for me?
item.description: The government could raise National Insurance to help pay for social care in England.

item.title: Feria: Rural memoirs stir longing for Spain's past
item.description: Ana Iris Simón's autobiographical book triggers a frenzied debate about the loss of village life.

item.title: Joe Ferrari: The high-rolling life of Thailand's controversial ex-police chief
item.description: Joe Ferrari, who is said to own 42 cars, was last month pictured torturing a suspect to death.

item.title: Tanni Grey-Thompson column: 'Great moments in Tokyo but Para-sport faces challenges'
item.description: Baroness Tanni Grey-Thompson reflects on Great Britain's performance at the Tokyo Paralympics and what comes next for Para-sport.

item.title: Has Covid killed off business cards for good?
item.description: Sales of business cards have fallen sharply as a result of the pandemic.

item.title: Paralympics: ‘We the disabled community are here to stay’
item.description: Four champions share their glory and their pain from the 16th Paralympic Games in Tokyo.

item.title: Solheim Cup 2021: Matilda Castren claims winning point as Europe retain the trophy
item.description: Rookie Leona Maguire stars as Europe retain the Solheim Cup with a hard-fought 15-13 victory over the United States in Ohio.

item.title: England crumble as inspired India sweep to victory - highlights & report
item.description: England's batting disintegrates in the face of an inspired India, who win the fourth Test by 157 runs to take a 2-1 lead in the series.

item.title: Brazil v Argentina: Fifa 'regrets' scenes leading to match suspension
item.description: Fifa says it "regrets" the scenes leading to the suspension of Brazil and Argentina's World Cup qualifier on Sunday.

item.title: Brazil legend Pele has surgery to remove tumour
item.description: Legendary Brazil forward Pele, 80, has surgery to remove a tumour from his colon.

item.title: England v India highlights: Tourists seal fourth Test victory with superb bowling display
item.description: England's batting folds under an inspired spell of bowling from India, who sweep to a 157-run victory on the final day at The Oval to take a 2-1 lead in the series.

item.title: Afghanistan: Rural areas welcome peace and end of war
item.description: In more rural areas of Afghanistan, people welcome the end of a war that has killed tens of thousands.

item.title: US Senator Lindsey Graham: 'We will be going back into Afghanistan'
item.description: Republican Senator Lindsey Graham believes there will be no choice as "the threat will be so large".

item.title: Afghanistan: Taliban accused of killing pregnant police officer
item.description: The killing comes amid increasing reports of escalating repression of women in Afghanistan.

item.title: Afghanistan: What's life like since the Taliban took over?
item.description: People around the country tell the BBC they have lost basic freedoms and are struggling to survive.

item.title: Afghanistan: Despair of Brits and UK allies stuck behind Taliban lines
item.description: An NHS worker, a teacher and families trapped in Afghanistan tell the BBC about their plans now.

item.title: Afghanistan women's cricket team: Players hiding in Kabul fear Taliban rule
item.description: Members of Afghanistan's women's cricket team are hiding in Kabul, fearing for their safety following the Taliban's return to power.

item.title: British soldier describes caring for Kabul airport baby
item.description: Lt Col Ben Caesar helped look after the baby who was pulled over the airport wall in Afghanistan.

item.title: Life under the Taliban: Where is your male escort?
item.description: Lyse Doucet takes the temperature on the streets of the Afghan capital as the Taliban tighten their grip.

item.title: Kabul drone strike: The key questions about a US attack
item.description: Ten Afghan civilians died when the US targeted a vehicle it says was linked to an imminent bombing.

item.title: Afghanistan: Taliban parade captured equipment in Kandahar
item.description: The militant group showcased the kit captured during their takeover of Afghanistan.

item.title: Covid: Which children are being vaccinated and why?
item.description: Millions of children, including 16- to 17-year-olds, are now being offered a Covid vaccine.

item.title: Back to school: How are pupils being kept Covid-safe?
item.description: Many children are returning to school after the holidays, while Scottish pupils already returned.

item.title: Covid-19 in the UK: How many coronavirus cases are there in my area?
item.description: Explore the data on coronavirus in the UK and find out how many cases there are in your area.

item.title: Covid: How is furlough changing and when will it end?
item.description: The furlough scheme, which protected millions of jobs during the pandemic, is in its final weeks.

item.title: Covid passports: Nightclubs, concerts and festivals... where will I need one?
item.description: Covid passports to prove vaccination will be required from the end of September in crowded indoor venues in England.

item.title: What are the holiday rules for travel to green, amber and red list countries?
item.description: A traffic light system is in place setting out rules for entering the UK

item.title: The hard men removing squatters in Spain
item.description: Some squatters in Spain demand cash before leaving - so eviction firms have arisen to handle the talks.

item.title: Afghanistan: Shukria Barakzai's whispered voice notes and dramatic escape
item.description: The desperate messages sent by Afghan politician Shukria Barakzai to a UK MP as the Taliban tried to hunt her down.

item.title: Afghanistan: The 'undefeated' Panjshir Valley - an hour from Kabul
item.description: The Panjshir Valley has been a flashpoint in Afghanistan's turbulent history - now it's happening again.

item.title: Bilal Sarwary: 'The plane hit the tower and all our lives changed'
item.description: Afghan journalist Bilal Sarwary was selling carpets when 9/11 happened. From that day on, everything changed.

item.title: Shot in the head in Angola, left for dead, now a Wetherspoons star
item.description: Cesar Kimbirima fled Angola after being shot four times and spending five months in a coma.
